generif.text: Human WAT STAMP2 associates with obesity and insulin resistance independently of adiponectin.
Down-regulation of STEAP4 is associated with obesity in humans.
TIARP/STAMP2 is highly upregulated in 3T3-L1 cells and hMSC-Ad by IL-1beta and might, therefore, modulate proinflammatory and insulin resistance-inducing effects of IL-1beta.
STEAP4 associates with focal adhesion kinase (FAK) and regulate the activity of FAK through Y397 phosphorylation.
Results demonstrate that STEAP4 does not influence human adipocyte differentiation, but it participates in regulating the insulin sensitivity of human adipocytes.
Observational study of gene-disease association and gene-environment interaction. (HuGE Navigator)
common polymorphisms of STAMP2 are unlikely to significantly contribute to the risk of the metabolic syndrome in the general population
Observational study of gene-disease association. (HuGE Navigator)

Fourteen novel and six known single nucleotide polymorphisms (SNPs) including 2 nonsynonymous SNPs in the STEAP4 gene were identified. SNPs rs8122 and rs1981529 were significantly associated with the metabolic syndrome phenotype in females.
Observational study of gene-disease association. (HuGE Navigator)
There was no association of the three polymorphisms (rs8122, rs1981529 and rs34741656) in the STAMP2 gene with essential hypertension in Xinjiang Uygur population.
STEAP 4 genetic polymorphisms may be associated with metabolic syndrome risk in Chinese Uygur population.
The knockdown of STEAP4 inhibits insulin-stimulated glucose transport and GLUT4 translocation via the attenuated phosphorylation of Akt, independent of the effects of EEA1.
STEAP4 might potentially suppress the pathogenesis of TNFalpha-induced arthritis such as rheumatoid arthritis.
STEAP4 genetic variations are likely to be associated with obesity-related insulin resistance in Uygur Chinese general population.
Decreased STAMP2 expression (mRNA and protein) might reflect visceral adipose dysfunction in subjects with obesity and type 2 diabetes.
an association of the common variation rs1981529 (Gly75Asp, 224A/G) in the STEAP4 gene with obesity in Uygur general population
STEAP4 is expressed on monocytes and neutrophils in peripheral blood of patients with rheumatoid arthritis.
STAMP2 antagonizes HBx-mediated hepatocyte dysfunction, thereby protecting hepatocytes from hepatitis B virus gene expression.
three polymorphisms (rs8122, rs1981529 and rs34741656) of STAMP2 gene may be not related with type 2 diabetes mellitus in Xinjiang Uygur population
Our results show increased mRNA expression of STEAP4 and NGAL in human visceral adipose tissue in obese patients.
STEAP4 was highly induced in human adipose cells differentiated in the presence of 1,25D.
Our findings revealed that STAMP2 gene polymorphisms are likely to significantly contribute to the risk of MetS in male Han Chinese population.

These data suggest that STAMP2 is required for prostate cancer progression and thus may serve as a novel therapeutic target.
Some SNPs of the STEAP4 gene altered the risk of developing a metabolic syndrome in the Han Chinese population.

The expression of TNFAIP9 significantly decreased in the adipose tissue of obese children, and its levels are closely related to blood lipid level, insulin resistance, and obesity.
the expression of STEAP4 was significantly downregulated in the adipose tissue of obese children.
These findings suggest that increased STEAP4 mRNA expression is associated with inflammatory stimuli, whereas lower STEAP4 expression is associated with obesity in human islets.
STEAP4 plays role in metal homeostasis is critical to the maintenance of cellular homeostasis , and in preventing the onset of metabolic disease. [review]

this study identified specific up-regulation of spliced variant STEAP4 in rheumatoid arthritis monocytes. This variant of STEAP4 might play a crucial role in the production of TNF-alpha and IL-6 through NF-kappaB and STAT-3 pathways, resulting in the generation of rheumatoid arthritis
cryo-electron microscopy structures of human STEAP4 in absence and presence of Fe(3+)-NTA, are reported.

STEAP4 modulates cell proliferation and oxidative stress in benign prostatic hyperplasia.

name: STEAP4 metalloreductase
other_names: seven chromosome locus associated with HCC
summary: The protein encoded by this gene belongs to the STEAP (six transmembrane epithelial antigen of prostate) family, and resides in the golgi apparatus. It functions as a metalloreductase that has the ability to reduce both Fe(3+) to Fe(2+) and Cu(2+) to Cu(1+), using NAD(+) as acceptor. Studies in mice and human suggest that this gene maybe involved in adipocyte development and metabolism, and may contribute to the normal biology of the prostate cell, as well as prostate cancer progression. Alternatively spliced transcript variants encoding different isoforms have been found for this gene. [provided by RefSeq, Apr 2011].
